questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband 2 hours after the onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. Her symptoms started shortly after she received a phone call from a family member informing her that her youngest son had died during elective surgery. She has a history of hypertension and chronic gastritis. She does not smoke, drink, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 162/88 mm Hg. An ECG performed in the emergency department shows ST elevations in leads V1–V3. An ECG performed two weeks ago at a routine health maintenance visit showed no abnormalities. Serum studies show a troponin I concentration of 1.06 ng/mL. Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography shows no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows apical dilation of the left ventricular myocardium and a hypercontractile left ventricular base. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While endocardial fibroelastosis can manifest with features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea), it is associated with diffuse thickening of the left ventricular endocardium (due to the proliferation of fibrous and elastic tissue) and restrictive cardiomyopathy. The size of ventricles is usually normal and apical ventricular dilation is not expected. Moreover, the condition most commonly manifests in the first few years of life with a gradual onset of symptoms. Chest pain, ST elevations, and increased cardiac enzymes are not typical manifestations.

B) CORRECT:

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs as a result of a catecholamine surge following intense emotional stress or severe illness. The catecholamine surge leads to cardiotoxicity and subsequent reversible left ventricular dysfunction. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and acute coronary syndrome (ACS) have similar manifestations, such as increased cardiac enzymes and signs of ischemia on ECG (e.g., ST-segment elevation), but coronary angiography shows no obstructive coronary artery disease in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Left ventricular wall motion abnormalities that extend beyond the vascular distribution of a single coronary artery are seen on echocardiography. Apical ballooning with a hypercontractile base is a characteristic finding but not seen in all patients. In hemodynamically stable patients, Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is generally treated as heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and therapy commonly involves ACE inhibitors and beta blockers. In hemodynamically unstable patients, vasopressor support may be required.

C) INCORRECT:

Vasospastic angina can be triggered by stress and manifest with sudden-onset chest pain, dyspnea, and transient ST elevations, but it does not result in troponin elevation (since there is no infarction) or structural changes in the ventricular myocardium. Moreover, coronary angiography shows evidence of coronary artery spasm when performed in symptomatic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

While myocardial hibernation can manifest with features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea), it is caused by chronic ischemic heart disease and manifests with ventricular hypokinesia on echocardiography. Additionally, the absence of any abnormalities on coronary angiography and a normal ECG two weeks ago rule out chronic ischemic heart disease in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular pseudoaneurysm, which typically occurs 3–14 days after a transmural myocardial infarction (MI), can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, new ST changes, and ventricular outpouching. Although a silent MI may occur in older women, the absence of any late post-MI ECG changes (e.g., persistent T-wave inversion, pathological Q waves, poor R-wave progression) both at the time of presentation and two weeks ago rule out a recent MI. Moreover, ventricular outpouching of a ventricular pseudoaneurysm is contained by the pericardium and results from a defect in the myocardial wall. This type of outpouching is distinct from apical dilation of the ventricular myocardium.
Image Description:

Transthoracic echocardiogram (apical 4-chamber view) of a 61-year-old patient with ST elevations and a 10-day history of chest pain and progressive dyspnea

The myocardium is disrupted at the apex and a large saccular outpouching extends into the pericardial space. Turbulent blood flow is seen between the ventricle and the pericardial outpouching.

These findings are consistent with a left ventricular pseudoaneurysm.
questions.hint: This patient, who presents with chest pain, ST elevations, and increased cardiac enzymes but no abnormalities on cardiac catheterization, most likely has a condition caused by a stress-induced catecholamine surge.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after the onset of shortness of breath and chest pain, which started shortly after she learned that her youngest son had died. She has no history of illness. She does not smoke, drink, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 162/88 mm Hg. An ECG performed in the emergency department shows ST elevations in leads V1–V3. An ECG performed two weeks ago at a routine health maintenance visit showed no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography shows no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows apical dilation of the left ventricular myocardium and a hypercontractile left ventricular base. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While endocardial fibroelastosis can manifest with features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea), it is associated with diffuse thickening of the left ventricular endocardium (due to the proliferation of fibrous and elastic tissue) and restrictive cardiomyopathy. The size of ventricles is usually normal and apical ventricular dilation is not expected. Moreover, the condition most commonly manifests in the first few years of life with a gradual onset of symptoms. Chest pain, ST elevations, and increased cardiac enzymes are not typical manifestations.

B) CORRECT:

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs as a result of a catecholamine surge following intense emotional stress or severe illness. The catecholamine surge leads to cardiotoxicity and subsequent reversible left ventricular dysfunction. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and acute coronary syndrome (ACS) have similar manifestations, such as increased cardiac enzymes and signs of ischemia on ECG (e.g., ST-segment elevation), but coronary angiography shows no obstructive coronary artery disease in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Left ventricular wall motion abnormalities that extend beyond the vascular distribution of a single coronary artery are seen on echocardiography. Apical ballooning with a hypercontractile base is a characteristic finding but not seen in all patients. In hemodynamically stable patients, Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is generally treated as heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and therapy commonly involves ACE inhibitors and beta blockers. In hemodynamically unstable patients, vasopressor support may be required.

C) INCORRECT:

Vasospastic angina can be triggered by stress and manifest with sudden-onset chest pain, dyspnea, and transient ST elevations, but it does not result in troponin elevation (since there is no infarction) or structural changes in the ventricular myocardium. Moreover, coronary angiography shows evidence of coronary artery spasm when performed in symptomatic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

While myocardial hibernation can manifest with features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea), it is caused by chronic ischemic heart disease and manifests with ventricular hypokinesia on echocardiography. Additionally, the absence of any abnormalities on coronary angiography and a normal ECG two weeks ago rule out chronic ischemic heart disease in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular pseudoaneurysm, which typically occurs 3–14 days after a transmural myocardial infarction (MI), can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, new ST changes, and ventricular outpouching. Although a silent MI may occur in older women, the absence of any late post-MI ECG changes (e.g., persistent T-wave inversion, pathological Q waves, poor R-wave progression) both at the time of presentation and two weeks ago rule out a recent MI. Moreover, ventricular outpouching of a ventricular pseudoaneurysm is contained by the pericardium and results from a defect in the myocardial wall. This type of outpouching is distinct from apical dilation of the ventricular myocardium.
questions.hint: This patient, who presents with chest pain, ST elevations, and increased cardiac enzymes but no abnormalities on cardiac catheterization, most likely has a condition caused by a stress-induced catecholamine surge.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with chest pain and dyspnea that began 6 hours after her daughter was in a car accident. Past medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Vital signs are BP, 87/61; P, 95; R, 18; SpO2, 96%. ECG shows ST elevation in leads aVR, V1, V2, and V3 without reciprocal changes. Troponin I is 2.1 ng/mL. The echocardiogram is shown; the left ventricular ejection fraction is 35%. There is evidence of mild left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous diuretics such as furosemide should be avoided in patients with suspected Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, especially if there is LVOT obstruction. Diuretics can worsen preload reduction and exacerbate LVOT obstruction, potentially precipitating cardiogenic shock. The reduced ejection fraction of 35% suggests significant left ventricular dysfunction, and volume depletion could be detrimental.

B) INCORRECT:

Inotropic support with dobutamine is inappropriate because of the presence of LVOT obstruction. In patients with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and LVOT obstruction, inotropes can precipitate cardiogenic shock and worsen the condition.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ECG pattern of ST elevation in aVR, together with elevations in V1–V3 and no reciprocal changes, strongly suggests Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. However, the combination of markedly elevated troponin levels (Takotsubo is usually associated with mild elevations) and cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension and hypercholesterolemia) necessitates emergency coronary angiography to definitively exclude acute coronary syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI is useful for characterizing myocardial edema and confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in stable patients, but it is not the immediate next step for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The ECG pattern and echocardiogram findings suggest Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, for which thrombolytic therapy is not indicated.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with acute chest pain that began 30 minutes after learning of her son's car accident. She reports substernal pressure with dyspnea. Vital signs are stable. ECG shows ST elevations in leads V2-V5 without reciprocal changes. Bedside echocardiogram reveals apical wall motion abnormalities with reduced ejection fraction. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Make definitive diagnosis using diagnostic criteria prior to treatment

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Emergency coronary angiography is usually required to rule out acute coronary syndrome, as it is extremely difficult to distinguish takotsubo cardiomyopathy from ACS based on ECG and laboratory findings alone.

B) INCORRECT:

While BNP levels are elevated in takotsubo cardiomyopathy, the immediate priority is excluding acute coronary syndrome given the ST elevations on EKG.

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic criteria such as the InterTAK diagnostic score can help determine pretest probability of takotsubo cardiomyopathy versus ACS, but given this presentation mimicking STEMI, urgent angiography should not be delayed for risk stratification.

D) INCORRECT:

Continuous telemetry monitoring is appropriate for takotsubo cardiomyopathy patients, but this is not the immediate priority.

E) INCORRECT:

Discharge would be inappropriate for a patient with acute chest pain, ST elevations, elevated troponin, and wall motion abnormalities requiring urgent evaluation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presents with chest pain and dyspnea that started 3 hours ago, shortly after witnessing a motor vehicle collision. Vital signs are BP, 88/55; P, 105; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1–V4 with prolonged QT interval. Echocardiogram is shown; there is also evidence of left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Troponin I is 1.9 ng/mL. Coronary angiography shows normal coronary arteries. After initiating supportive care, the patient's heart rate increases to 115 and they develop worsening hypotension to 75/45 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Give IV fluid bolus and initiate low-dose esmolol

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- IV fluids increase preload, which may improve left ventricular filling and reduce obstruction. Short-acting beta blockers such as esmolol can help relieve left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, but they must be used with caution in patients with hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine is contraindicated in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Inotropic agents increase contractility and can worsen the dynamic obstruction, potentially precipitating cardiogenic shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Intra-aortic balloon pump is contraindicated in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. The balloon pump increases afterload reduction, which can worsen the dynamic obstruction and hemodynamic compromise.

D) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are contraindicated in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Furosemide reduces preload, which can worsen the dynamic obstruction by decreasing left ventricular filling and increasing the pressure gradient across the outflow tract.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin and other vasodilators are contraindicated in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Vasodilation reduces preload and afterload, which can worsen the dynamic obstruction and hemodynamic status.
